data.title: Errors are not removed automatically when fixing them on an another file
data.body:
I have noticed that errors in one current file are not removed automatically when I fix them in an another file where the error originates from. 

Non-existent has red squiggles:

``` typescript
import { nonexistent } from './some-where.ts';
```

And then define in `some-where.ts`:

``` typescript
export function nonexistent () {}
```

Then the error in the first file is not removed. I need to type something then it will be removed.

data.title: CodeAlpha can't be started from command prompt
data.body:
- Install Code Alpha only. 
- Check add code to path.
- in command type code or codeAlpha 

Observe: both fail.

code.cmd refers to Code.exe, however in Alpha channel code is named CodeAlpha.

data.title: Horizontal panel - output and repl
data.body:
- [x] win @dbaeumer 
- [x] mac @egamma 
- [x] linux @jrieken 

We are now showing output and debug repl in the horizontal panel. There is a general horizontal panel test item #2173, so no need to test that. Verify:
- you can **toggle** repl using the global debug actions or from the view menu
- repl behaves as before
  - automatically **shows up** when starting a debug session
  - repl **wraps words**
  - **input box** always on bottom and always focussed
  - you can **inspect** complex variables
- you can **toggle** output from the view menu and you can change output channels
- output behaves as before
  - automatically **shows up** when a task is started
  - last line **revelead** when output comes
  - **link detection** works

data.title: Support for GitHub Flavored Markdown

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
In the Common Questions section of https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/markdown it says "Code supports GitHub Flavored Markdown".

This support is incomplete as at least Code's internal preview does not render task lists correctly. They are described as part of GFM here: https://help.github.com/articles/writing-on-github/

Please add this to Code's previewer.

data.title: [js] Salsa - JS ReactNative - use the TypeScriptReact grammar for JS
data.body:
To support ReactNative, which uses JSX constructs inside .js files, We should use the typescriptReact grammar for JS.

Salsa will also make the change to use the JSX parser for JS.

data.title: Horizontal panel - general
data.body:
- [x] win @dbaeumer 
- [x] mac @egamma 
- [x] linux @jrieken 

We introduced a concept of the horizontal panel to the workbench. For specific output and repl functionality there is #2176, so no need to test that. Verify:
- You can **toggle** the panel, either from the view menu or using the shortcuts
- You can nicely **resize** the horizontal panel using the sash which causes smooth layouting
- When opened horizontal panel always **restores** it's size and opens the last active panel (repl, git output, task output)
- Horizontal panel has a **maximum** size, and a **minimum** size below which it is minimized like the sidebar
- Be creative and try to **break** the workbench layout by minimizing / maximizing components, moving sidebar to the right, toggling visibility...

- Only the changed variables since the last break are indicated

data.title: args in launch.json not getting picked up.
Remove static welcome page and move welcome experience to the website
data.body:
The welcome page is static and does not provide a lot of value. This change will stop showing the welcome page on first run experience, it will instead open a tailored welcome page in code.visualstudio.com. 

Taking the welcome page out of VSCode will allow us to change it more rapidly and customized it for user needs. 

The change include: 
- Remove ShowWelcomeAction from the menu and stop rendering the welcome page on first run. 
- It will reuse welcomePage env variable to supply the URL that VSCode will open on first start.

data.title: Method Intellisense mangled & truncated
data.body:
Playing around with ASP.NET Core and noticed that the pop-up intellisense for one of the API's I am accessing appears to be broken in several ways:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/961950/12498200/94c53c44-c055-11e5-8374-9d1b1696aa73.png)

The text is:
1. Garbled - the API text doesn't appear to be readable end-user intellisense
2. Truncated - the API text/docs are truncated to the right

Running VS Code 0.10.6 on Windows 10 11099 on Surface Pro 4.

data.title: Problem installing extension
data.body:
If I try to install the extension, vscode asks to restart, then after restarting I see an "issue" at the bottom left of the vscode window.

[c:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/extensions/csharp-o]: Cannot read file c:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/extensions/csharp-o/package.json: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open 'c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\csharp-o\package.json'

This also breaks the install system, as the extension is half installed, I had to remove the extensions folder to fix that.

data.title: Expose extension URL for SSL white listing
data.body:
doc feedback verbatim:
"please put the extensions url that visual studio code tries to reach (all of them) when installing an extension. we use ssl inspection and installation is failing because of certificates. but I'm not able to whitelist the urls"

data.title: VS Code takes over .js file icon and type
data.body:
On Windows install, VS Code is taking over .js and various .js flavor file extension icon and file type.  In Windows explorer, the user no longer sees the JavaScript icon and the detail file Type is "Visual Studio Code".
.php is also overridden.
doc feedback verbatim: "All my files show up with similar icon and similar file description type. It is hard to distinguish now which is the .php file and which is .css file. Even changing registry values doesn't help. It still opens with Code (that's OK) but the icons and file descriptions are very confusing. All my files now show "Visual Studio Code" and nothing else."

data.title: Provide Intellisense for module import
data.body:
TypeScript module exports can be fairly opaque in regard to their exports. Particularly when modules grow bigger. With bigger modules (particularly with modules exporting other modules' exports) it becomes very hard to see which entities a module actually is exporting.
##### So I suggest to provide an Intellisense feature for module imports, which 1. provides a file browser dropdown box displaying valid module files 2. provides a module browser dropdown box displaying an imported module's exported entities
#### The first part of the suggestion I propose to work like `LINQ`: After entering the keyword `from` and hitting the [TAB] key, a file browser dropdown should be displayed, listing all valid module files. After confirming a file from the dropdown box, VS Code should automatically create a full `import {} from "[...]"` statement, move the cursor position between the curly braces and display a dropdown box listing all the exports of that module.
##### Here's a visualization: ![provide intellisense for import](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9283914/12483755/17e59744-c057-11e5-9992-599d511cf826.gif)
#### The second part of the suggestion I propose to work like common Intellisense: Everytime when hitting [CTRL]+[SPACE] from within the curly braces of an `import` statement, dropdown box (2) should be displayed, listing the module's exported entities. Selecting an entry should then add the selected export entity to the list of already imported entities within the curly braces.

data.title: Test TextEditor.viewColumn
data.body:
- [x] any os @bpasero

With #1835 we exposed the view column of an editor and signal changes of it via an event. Make sure that
- the field is set and reflects the current view state
- the field is unset for inplace editor (reference search zone widget et al)
- there is an event that fires when view columns change (rearrange, close, open editor)

data.title: Working Files list should be ordered by last viewed.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm currently ignoring the Working Files window because I'm not finding it entirely useful.
As I'm working with files, I've memorised the location of the files I'm switching between and the list stays fairly static so its easy to go from one file or another.

The working files windows however I'm assuming is ordered by when opened, so it changes across coding sessions.

I, personally, would find it more useful if it acted like a stack. Anytime I switch to a file, it should raise to the top of the working files list, and so the first item is the active file, and the second is the last viewed file.

In essence, the list should be ordered by last viewed.

Not sure if anyone shares my preference here, but I'd be interested to hear for or otherwise.

data.title: Consider changing IDE name
data.body:
I think Visual Studio Code is terrible name for this IDE, because:
1. If I google for any problem, 50 % I get search result for Visual Studio, not for Visual Studio Code.
2. Code word don't really help you know different between Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code.
3. Word Code in visual studio have more meanings. for example it can be actual source code.

My suggestions: Visual Studio Light, any other words except Visual Studio

data.title: IntelliSense in line comments
data.body:
After upgrading to VSCode 0.10.6 I've been getting IntelliSense suggestions when writing a line comment (starting the line with //) in C# projects. I use VScode for developing Unity3D projects on OSX 10.11.2.

It's an understatement to call it annoying when I write e.g. "will do" and "do" auto completes to a full do...while loop.
